subj-group.subject: Special Section: Emotion and Approach and Avoidance Motivation

title-group.article-title: Approach–Avoidance versus Dominance–Submissiveness: A Multilevel Neural Framework on How Testosterone Promotes Social Status

contrib-group.aff: Department of Psychology, Utrecht University, The Netherlands
Department of Psychiatry & Mental Health, University of Cape Town, South Africa

author-notes.corresp: David Terburg, Department of Psychology, Utrecht University, Heidelberglaan 2, Utrecht 3584 CS, The Netherlands. Email: d.terburg@uu.nl

abstract.p: Approach–avoidance generally describes appetitive motivation and fear of punishment. In a social context approach motivation is, however, also expressed as social aggression and dominance. We therefore link approach–avoidance to dominance–submissiveness, and provide a neural framework that describes how the steroid hormone testosterone shifts reflexive as well as deliberate behaviors towards dominance and promotion of social status. Testosterone inhibits acute fear at the level of the basolateral amygdala and hypothalamus and promotes reactive dominance through upregulation of vasopressin gene expression in the central-medial amygdala. Finally, the hormone can, depending on social context and prenatal hormone exposure, promote both pro- and antisocial behaviors and decisions through its effects on prefrontal–amygdala interactions. All these effects of testosterone, however, serve to increase and maintain social status.

sec.title: Social Approach–Avoidance and Dominance–Submissiveness
sec.p: Generally, humans and other animals only take action in pursuit of something desirable (approach), or to escape punishment (avoidance). The term approach seems, however, not sufficient when used within the social context as it also strongly relates to anger and aggression (Carver & Harmon-Jones, 2009). Important in this respect is that anxious and aggressive personalities typically dissociate in their basic reaction to social threat. Both respond vigilantly, but the first will subsequently avoid it, whereas the second will approach and confront it in search of a rewarding outcome (Carver & Harmon-Jones, 2009). Anger and social aggression are strongly linked to dominance motives, and social anxiety to submissiveness (Trower & Gilbert, 1989; Weeks, Heimberg, & Heuer, 2011). For these reasons, we will discuss social approach–avoidance behavior throughout this review in these terms. In this view submissiveness describes avoidance, fear, and punishment sensitivity, whereas the term dominance captures appetitive motivation as well as anger and social aggression.

sec.title: Testosterone, Dominance–Submissiveness, and the Amygdala
sec.p: Angry eye contact is a means of dominant-aggressive communication in several rodent species (Brecht & Freiwald, 2011), and a main factor in the formation of social hierarchies within primate groups (Mazur & Booth, 1998). When two primates establish eye contact, a staring contest may arise until the subordinate averts gaze to prevent a violent confrontation. In other words, high-ranked primates tend to angrily outstare lower ranked conspecifics. We recently showed that these mechanisms can also be observed in humans. Submissive individuals rapidly avert gaze after making eye contact with angry faces (Terburg, Aarts, & van Honk, 2012a), and in a recent interactive eye-tracked gaze aversion study (EGA; see Figure 1A) we showed that this dominance–submission mechanism of gaze aversion in humans is implicit and reflexive (Terburg, Hooiveld, Aarts, Kenemans, & van Honk, 2011; see Figure 1B).

caption.p: Eye-Tracked Gaze-Aversion (EGA) task (see online article for color version; figures adapted from Terburg, Aarts, & van Honk, 2012b; Terburg et al., 2011). (A) Example trial; participants watch grey pictures change color, upon which gaze is shifted to the dot with the same color. Unknown to the participants, facial expressions are presented during color transition, which makes the gaze shift an implicit act of gaze aversion. (B) Correlations of dominant and nondominant behavioral activation scales (BAS) with the contrast of angry and happy faces: High contrast scores represent longer saccade latencies for angry trials, that is, inhibition of submissive gaze aversion. (C) Gaze aversion latency from angry versus happy faces, and conscious motivational states. After testosterone administration gaze aversion from angry faces is slower, while conscious motivational states are unaffected.

sec.p: As described before, dominance motives reflect appetitive motivation and social aggression, and the steroid hormone testosterone seems involved in both. Firstly, testosterone modulates the dopamine system, which strongly relates to reward and sex drive (Hermans et al., 2010; Hull, Du, Lorrain, & Matuszewich, 1997). Secondly, in many species testosterone is causally involved in aggression (Nelson & Trainor, 2007), but only in social aggression against conspecifics (Archer, 2006). Moreover, recent evidence suggests that testosterone can promote social cooperative behavior, which would stem from the motivation to increase social status (Eisenegger, Naef, Snozzi, Heinrichs, & Fehr, 2010). Both social aggression and status drives are crucial in the formation of dominance hierarchies, and testosterone administration indeed seems involved as it induces cardiac acceleration in response to angry faces (van Honk et al., 2001) and activity in a brain network implicated in dominance and social aggression (Hermans, Ramsey, & van Honk, 2008). Recently we confirmed a causal relationship between dominance and testosterone as women showed more reactive dominance to subliminally presented angry faces on the EGA task after testosterone administration (Terburg, Aarts, & van Honk, 2012b; see Figure 1C).

Interestingly, similar to testosterone, vasopressin gene-expression is related to social, but not to predatory, aggression (Wersinger, Caldwell, Christiansen, & Young, 2007), and it has been argued that vasopressin plays a role in the profound sex differences in social aggressive behavior (de Vries, 2008; Scordalakes & Rissman, 2004). Importantly, testosterone upregulates vasopressin gene expression in the central-medial amygdala (CMA; Goudsmit, Luine, & Swaab, 1990; Szot & Dorsa, 1994), which has been linked to the promotion of aggressive action in subcortical areas (Bosch & Neumann, 2011; Huber, Veinante, & Stoop, 2005; Koolhaas, van Den Brink, Roozendaal, & Boorsma, 1990). Moreover, both testosterone and vasopressin administration studies showed a selective decline in the ability to recognize negative emotions from faces, which is argued to underlie social aggressive tendencies (Uzefovsky, Shalev, Israel, Knafo, & Ebstein, 2012; van Honk & Schutter, 2007). Combined, these findings suggest that the mechanism by which testosterone implicitly predisposes the individual for reactive social aggression and dominance is through the upregulation of vasopressin gene expression in the CMA (van Honk, Terburg, & Bos, 2011).

Testosterone has also profound fear-reducing properties. Testosterone inhibits the hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis which is heavily involved in fear and stress (Terburg, Morgan, & van Honk, 2009; Viau, 2002); and in rats testosterone reduces fear, both through its direct effects on the androgen receptor and indirectly via the gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptor (Aikey, Nyby, Anmuth, & James, 2002; Fernandez-Guasti & Martinez-Mota, 2005; Michels & Hoppe, 2008). It must, however, be noted that blockade of vasopressin receptors in the basolateral amygdala (BLA), but not in the CMA, also reduces fear (Salomé, Stemmelin, Cohen, & Griebel, 2006). The effects of testosterone on the BLA’s vasopressin system has, to our knowledge, not yet been studied, but given testosterone’s fear-reducing qualities, it seems unlikely that testosterone also upregulates vasopressin in the BLA like it does in the CMA. This, however, does not exclude that testosterone affects the BLA, but this influence might be more direct on androgen receptors as these have been shown to be increased in the BLA of pathologically aggressive dogs (Jacobs, van den Broeck, & Simoens, 2006).

Interestingly, recently we showed that selective damage to the human BLA was associated with hyper-vigilant reflexive responding to facial fear (Terburg, Morgan, et al., 2012). We argued that through attenuation of the output functions of the CMA, the BLA, together with the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC), can decrease fear responding in the hypothalamus and brainstem. Additionally, the BLA can directly modulate CMA functions, which leads particularly to the reduction of acute and innate fear responsivity (Macedo, Cuadra, Molina, & Brandao, 2005; Tye et al., 2011; Figure 2). An interesting parallel can be found in testosterone administration studies in humans who also show reduced acute fear responsivity, whereas conscious anxiety is generally not affected (Hermans et al., 2007; Hermans, Putman, Baas, Koppeschaar, & van Honk, 2006). Indeed, with exactly the same implicit fear vigilance paradigm that showed fear hyper-vigilance in patients with BLA damage, it was shown that testosterone administration results in fear hypo-vigilance (van Honk, Peper, & Schutter, 2005). A recent functonal magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study furthermore confirmed that testosterone administration increased dorsal amygdala activation in response to fearful faces, whereas the ventral amygdala, which includes the CMA, was not affected (Bos, van Honk, Ramsey, Stein, & Hermans, in press). Finally, it has been shown that the inhibitory and fear-reducing pathway from lateral to medial CMA (Ciocchi et al., 2010), which is the pathway by which the BLA controls the CMA (Tye et al., 2011), is independent from vasopressin (Huber et al., 2005; Veinante & Freund-Mercier, 1997). Upregulation of the vasopressin gene expression by testosterone in the CMA may thus increase social aggression, but leaves the fear-reducing properties of the BLA intact. Instead, these might even be upregulated by testosterone through its direct effects on the androgen receptor (Fernandez-Guasti & Martinez-Mota, 2005), but this should be addressed in future research.

caption.p: Heterogeneous amygdala functioning in threat vigilance. The BLA and OFC jointly regulate output of the CMA to the brainstem, resulting in controlled and adaptive fear vigilance.

sec.title: Testosterone and Decision Making
sec.p: Testosterone’s promotion of reflexive dominance behavior is inherently only triggered by direct social threats (van Honk, Terburg, & Bos, 2011). Testosterone, however, also affects behavior in nonthreatening situations. For instance, testosterone reduces trust (Bos, Terburg, & van Honk, 2010), and can reduce cognitive empathy (van Honk, Schutter, et al., 2011), but increase social cooperation (Eisenegger et al., 2010; van Honk, Montoya, Bos, van Vugt, & Terburg, 2012). A possible mechanism for these effects is through a decrease of cortical control over the amygdala, which we previously argued to underlie a “safeguarding mode” that drives higher order behavior to defend or increase social status (van Honk, Terburg, & Bos, 2011). Endogenous testosterone levels are indeed related to more aggressive decision making and simultaneously reduced activity in the OFC, a brain area consistently involved in the reduction of impulsive and aggressive behavior through its bidirectional connectivity with the amygdala (Mehta & Beer, 2010). Interestingly, when viewing angry faces, administration of testosterone increased OFC, amygdala, and hypothalamus activation (Hermans et al., 2008), while it also reduced functional connectivity between the amygdala and OFC (van Wingen, Mattern, Verkes, Buitelaar, & Fernandez, 2010). In congruence, testosterone decreases functional crosstalk between cortical and subcortical areas as measured with electroencephalography (EEG; Schutter & van Honk, 2004). These effects can be argued to reflect reduced prefrontal control over the amygdala’s aggressive reactivity. Indeed, psychopathy, a disorder strongly related to dominance, aggression, and high testosterone (Blair, 2003; Glenn, Raine, Schug, Gao, & Granger, 2010), is also characterized by reduced OFC–amygdala connectivity (Craig et al., 2009; Motzkin, Newman, Kiehl, & Koenigs, 2011).

One of the mechanisms underlying this reduced OFC control over the amygdala is the testosterone-induced upregulation of dopamine in the OFC (Aubele & Kritzer, 2011; Blasi et al., 2009; van Honk, Terburg, & Bos, 2011). This decoupling might drive the increasingly impulsive, risk-taking and reward-seeking tendencies associated with dopamine (Clark & Henderson, 2003), which has also been observed in psychopathy (Blair & Mitchell, 2008) and might even contribute to reactive social aggression when status is directly challenged. When the social context is nonthreatening, however, this OFC–amygdala decoupling might also underlie the status-driven cooperative behavior found after testosterone administration (Eisenegger et al., 2010; van Honk et al., 2012).

Additionally, the direction of testosterone’s effects on behavior in nonthreatening situations might depend on the amount of testosterone that is converted into estradiol, which has recently been argued to show profound individual differences (Sarachana, Xu, Wu, & Hu, 2011). It was first postulated by Manning, Scutt, Wilson, and Lewis-Jones (1998) that prenatal exposure to relatively high levels of testosterone is reflected in a low ratio between the length of the second and fourth digits of the right hand (2D:4D), and that individuals with a high 2D:4D were prenatally exposed to relatively high levels of estradiol (Breedlove, 2010; Lutchmaya, Baron-Cohen, Raggatt, Knickmeyer, & Manning, 2004). Furthermore, prenatal testosterone levels have been shown to influence brain development (Peper et al., 2009), predict physical aggression in men (Bailey & Hurd, 2005), and have been argued to modulate the effects testosterone has on behavior later in life (Terburg, Peper, Morgan, & van Honk, 2009). Hypothetically, individuals who have been prenatally primed by estradiol (high 2D:4D) might metabolize more testosterone into estradiol (Zheng & Cohn, 2011), and estradiol action on estrogen receptors might underlie the prosocial effects testosterone has in this group (van Honk et al., 2012). Accordingly, in individuals prenatally primed by testosterone (low 2D:4D), metabolization into estradiol is less prevalent and testosterone acts more directly on androgen receptors, resulting in the negative effects on cognitive empathy (van Honk, Schutter, et al., 2011).

It must be noted that in contrast to the effects of testosterone in nonthreatening contexts (van Honk et al., 2012; van Honk, Schutter, et al., 2011), the effect on reactive dominance as found with the EGA was independent from 2D:4D (see Figure 3; Terburg, Aarts, & van Honk, 2012b). Following our aforementioned argument, this suggests that testosterone’s effect on reactive dominance is not dependent on the amount of testosterone metabolized to estradiol. In support, not only testosterone, but also estradiol, have been argued to reduce fear (Bos, Panksepp, Bluthé, & van Honk, 2012), and although prenatal and early testosterone levels have strong organizational effects on vasopressin gene expression, testosterone as well as estradiol can upregulate vasopressin gene expression later in life (de Vries, 2008). The acute effects of testosterone in threatening contexts (e.g., reduced fear and increased aggression) might thus be independent from the amount of testosterone that converts to estradiol. To draw definite conclusions on these testosterone–estradiol interactions this model should, however, be further studied.

caption.p: 2D:4D significantly predicts the behavioral effects of testosterone administration on cognitive empathy (van Honk, Schutter et al., 2011) and social cooperation (van Honk et al., 2012), but not on reactive dominance (Terburg, Aarts, & van Honk, 2012b, see also Figure 1C [2D:4D data in this study was not reported previously]).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: We have postulated a model (Figure 4) on how testosterone promotes social approach behavior operationalized with the term dominance that includes reward sensitivity as well as social aggression. First, testosterone increases general reward sensitivity through upregulation of the dopamine system and decreases fear vigilance through its effect on the HPA axis, androgen, and GABA receptors. Next, testosterone increases aggressive vigilance in the CMA by upregulating vasopressin gene expression, and reduces prefrontal control over the CMA through, among other mechanisms, the upregulation of dopamine in the OFC. Additionally, testosterone might promote the inhibitive function of the BLA in acute fear responsivity. This model explains the dual role of testosterone on vigilant behavior: reductions in acute fear vigilance and stress, and increased reactive–reflexive aggressive tendencies. Finally, it provides a framework wherein testosterone underlies higher order behavior that is beneficial for social status. Possibly depending on prenatal hormone exposure, testosterone can decrease sociality by reducing cognitive empathy, but also increase social cooperation.

caption.p: Model of effects of testosterone on reactive as well as deliberate social behavior. In situations with direct social threat, testosterone’s effects on the BLA, CMA, and brainstem (see also Figure 2) promote aggression and fearlessness, resulting in reactive dominance. When no direct social threat is present, testosterone’s effect on cortical structures, and decoupling of the OFC and amygdala, drive decision-making behavior towards the defense and promotion of social status (social safeguarding). The amount of testosterone that is converted to estradiol hypothetically depends on prenatal exposure to testosterone and estradiol as measured with digit ratio (2D:4D), and modulates pro- or asocial effects of testosterone.

sec.p: In other words, testosterone prepares the individual for the defense of social status. Rooted in evolutionary biology, our model shows that testosterone’s influence on reactive–reflexive dominance and social aggression is automatic, unconscious, and subcortically driven by phylogenetically ancient brain mechanisms humans share with most other vertebrates. The framework furthermore extends the influence of testosterone to higher order human functioning, by showing how the hormone predisposes the individual to be always safeguarding its position in the social hierarchy. Since aggressive violence in our complex society is not always the best option for the defense or increase of social status (Dabbs & Dabbs, 2000), these effects of testosterone on higher order reasoning can also lead to socially cooperative, or prosocial, behaviors. Thus, testosterone adaptively promotes any social approach behavior that defends or increases social status.
